channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Report Details Overseas Accounts of Chinese Elite
item.description: A report divulges new details about the wealth of relatives of some of China’s most powerful leaders.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Relatives of senior Chinese officials, including President Xi Jinping, above, are among those whose overseas holdings are listed in a new report.

item.title: A Leader of Pro-Government Faction Shot in Thailand
item.description: Kwanchai Praipana, who runs a group that supports the government, was shot a day after Thailand’s prime minister declared emergency rule as tensions continue to fester with daily anti-government protests.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kwanchai Praipana is a leader of Thailand's pro-government Red Shirts movement.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Author Vikram Chandra
item.description: Mr. Chandra spoke to India Ink at the Jaipur Literature Festival about the research he did for his 2006 book, “Sacred Games,” its television adaptation and why he calls it an anti-thriller.
item.dc:creator: By AAYUSH SONI
item.media:description: Vikram Chandra, author of the book 'Sacred Games' at the Jaipur Literature Festival on Monday.

item.title: The Lede: Video Shows Toronto’s Mayor Using Jamaican Patois in Obscene Rant About Police Surveillance
item.description: Two months after he claimed to have embraced sobriety, Mayor Rob Ford was caught on video Monday complaining about police surveillance of him and his associates in a drunken, obscenity-laced rant.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of a photograph posted on Instagram early Tuesday showing Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto at a fast-food restaurant.

item.title: Military Eyes Afghan Force of 10,000, or a Pullout
item.description: The Pentagon has proposed to President Obama that 10,000 American troops remain in Afghanistan when the international combat mission there ends after this year, or none at all, senior government officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JACKIE CALMES and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Leader Expresses Support for Abused Maid
item.description: President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono joined thousands of Indonesian migrant workers abroad and at home on Tuesday in expressing outrage at the alleged torture of an Indonesian maid by her Hong Kong employer.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican Monsignor Suspected of Money Laundering
item.description: Monsignor Nunzio Scarano, already on trial for plotting to smuggle $26 million from Switzerland to Italy, was arrested Tuesday in a separate case, suspected of using his Vatican bank accounts to launder money.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Photo Archive Is Said to Show Widespread Torture in Syria
item.description: If genuine, the trove is new visual corroboration that Syria’s government is guilty of mass war crimes against its own citizens, just as it appeared to regain some international standing.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Photographs released by lawyers commissioned by the Qatari government, an opponent of Syria’s government, are being portrayed as part of an archive of torture under President Bashar al-Assad. The abuses are said to include “tramline injuries,” linear bruises from being beaten with a rod.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Embassy at the Vatican Will Reopen
item.description: Ireland is reopening its embassy to the Vatican more than two years after shutting it down in the wake of sex abuse cases.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Environment: 2013 Listed as One of the Warmest Years on Record
item.description: Two government agencies said Tuesday that 2013 was among the warmest years in the global temperature record, though they differed on exactly where it ranked.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS

item.title: More Problems for American Couple Accused in Qatar
item.description: An American accused with his wife of starving their daughter to death says his employer asked him to return to work, even though the couple could face the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and SHABINA S. KHATRI

item.title: For U.N. Chief, a Dance of Diplomacy Is Halted by a Misstep
item.description: A precise diplomatic sequence that relied Iran and the United States to perform failed, forcing Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, to stumble.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon and Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, in Montreux, Switzerland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Snowden Denies Suggestions That He Was a Spy for Russia
item.description: He called the accusation by congressional leaders “false,” saying he had “clearly and unambiguously acted alone, with no assistance from anyone, much less a government.”
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Peaceful Swiss Resort Takes On Troubles of Syrian War
item.description: The expectant melancholy typical of resort towns in the winter has given way in Montreux to something edgier as it gears up for Syrian peace talks.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Wartime Claim to Fame Divides 2 Italian Towns
item.description: Anzio is engraved in history books as the main landing site of forces that went on to liberate Rome. Now nearby Nettuno is seeking to stake its claim.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: About 8,000 Americans are buried at the Sicily-Rome American Cemetery in Nettuno.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Shanghai Doctor Dies of Bird Flu
item.description: Investigators are trying to determine if the doctor had contact with poultry or live birds, as in most previous H7N9 cases, or if he might have contracted the disease from a patient.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Health officials collecting geese at a poultry market in Zhuji, Zhejiang Province. The local government ordered all live poultry killed at two markets in Zhuji as a preventive measure against the H7N9 avian flu.

item.title: Nairobi Journal: Visiting Scene, Court Calls Forth Memories of Massacre at a Mall
item.description: A chief magistrate led a grim field trip to the Westgate mall in Nairobi, Kenya, the scene of a massacre, bringing along prosecutors, defense lawyers and even the suspects.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Officers stood guard Tuesday as trial participants toured the Westgate mall in Nairobi, where dozens were killed in September.

item.title: Investors Seek Yields in Europe, but Analysts Warn of Risk
item.description: Investors are piling into the government debt of bailed-out countries like Ireland. But the demand comes despite the problems still plaguing the euro zone.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: Global investors are buying up bonds in Europe, worrying some economists who see debt levels rising again in troubled nations.

item.title: U.S. and Russia Discuss Olympic Security
item.description: Military officials from both countries are talking about the use of sophisticated American equipment designed to counter improvised explosive devices.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

item.title: Twitter Q. and A. on Syria Peace Talks
item.description: Anne Barnard of The Times answered readers’ questions on the conflict in Syria and Wednesday’s peace conference.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by HANNA INGBER

item.title: Pakistan Goes After Militants in Northwest
item.description: The Pakistani government has come under increasing pressure to destroy militant bases after a series of recent attacks.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Ukraine’s Opposition Says Government Stirs Violence
item.description: Government opponents pointed to recent actions to intimidate demonstrators, like sending cellphone messages saying, “You are registered as a participant in a mass disturbance.”
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard during a rally held by protesters in Kiev on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China, a Week Full of Trials Over Dissent
item.description: At least seven citizens are due to stand trial for participating in the New Citizens Movement and other protest groups.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Excluded Iran Says Its Role at Talks on Syria Will Be Missed
item.description: After Iran was invited to and then disinvited from a coming peace conference on Syria, Iranian officials and commentators said it was the attendees who would be missing out.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Suicide Bomber Strikes in South Beirut, Killing at Least 4
item.description: The blast in an area where Hezbollah holds sway was the latest in a series of attacks that are being seen as retaliation for the role groups are playing in Syria’s civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: A man tried to extinguish burning cars following the explosion on Tuesday.
